div.lg:
Through storm-cloud and eclipse must move
Each Cause and Man, dear to the stars and Jove;
Nor always can the wisest tell
Deferred fulfillment from the hopeless knell—
The struggler from the floundering ne'er-do-well.
A pall-cloth on the Seven Days fell,
McClellan—
Unprosperously heroical!
Who could Antietam's wreathThe wreath here refers both to the figurative wreath that would crown the victor, as well as the many wreaths laid to commemorate the fallen. foretell?
Authority called you; then, in mist
And loom of jeopardy—dismissed.Due to Lincoln’s eagerness to mount an offensive against Lee’s army and McClellan’s hesitancy, the latter was removed as General-in-Chief in the spring of 1862, though he still retained command of the Potomac Army. Soon after, McClellan led the army in the Peninsula Campaign to take Richmond. After the bloody Seven Day’s battles that ended the Peninsula Campaign without the capture of Richmond, Lincoln relieved McClellan of his command, appointing Henry Halleck as General-in-Chief of the army and General John Pope as commander of the Army of the Potomac (https://www.civilwar.org/learn/biographies/george-b-mcclellan). Recalled you, nor endured delayLincoln reinstated McClellan as commander after John Pope failed to take Richmond in the battle of Second Manassas. McClellan moved the Union army to rout Lee’s march on Maryland in 1862.;
And forth you rode upon a blasted way,
Arrayed Pope's rout, and routed Lee's array,

Your tent was choked with captured flags that day Although Melville emphasizes the flags captured and brought to McClellan, the Union and Confederate forces suffered comparable losses in the battle.,
McClellan.
Antietam was a telling frayMcClellan’s maneuvers to rebuff Lee’s advance in Maryland culminated in the battle of Antietam, also known as the Battle of Sharpsburg, on September 17, 1862, known as the single bloodiest day of the war..

lg.l: Recalled you; and she heard your drum
Advancing through the ghastly gloom.
You manned the wall, you propped the Dome,
You stormed the powerful stormer home,
McClellan:
Antietam's cannon long shall boom.

l.note: Following the Peninsula Campaign, in which he failed to capture Richmond, McClellan withdrew his men to Aquia Creek, VA, and Alexandria, VA. Most of McClellan's men were reassigned to John Pope's command in August 1862 after McClellan was relieved of duty as commander of the Army of the Potomac.

lg.l: McClellan—
Your veterans sent from you, and thrown
To fields and fortunes all unknown—
What thoughts were yours, revealed to none,
While faithful still you labored on—

l.note: After McClellan's command was given to Major General John Pope, the latter met a withering defeat at the Battle of Second Manassas in August of 1862. McClellan was subsequently reinstated as commander of the Army of the Potomac.

lg.l: McClellan,
Only Antietam could atone.
You fought in the front (an evil day,
McClellan)—
The fore-front of the first assay;

The Cause went soundingHennig Cohen identifies “sounding” as one of several nautical puns in lines 45-46. “Sounding,” according to Cohen, can refer to “measuring depth for the purpose of safe navigation” but also “dropping down abruptly, and as a whaling term connotes uncertainty and suspense over when or whether the whale will surface” (Cohen 234). , groped its way;

The leadsmenIn lines 45-46, Hennig Cohen suggests that Melville offers several nautically-themed puns. As one of them, “leadsman” is someone who “takes soundings or measurements of depth with a lead-weighted line.” However, Cohen contends that the primary meaning for this line is of “a person who leads.” Cohen adds that this signification “is re-enforced by the fact that (leadsman) is a variant of (lodesman), meaning leader, guide, pilot or steersman (N.E.D.) (234). quarrelled in the bayHennig Cohen identifies this phrase as one of three nautical puns in lines 45-46. This phrase of course “refers to a body of water and to the state of being held in check, at bay” (234).;
Quills thwarted swords; divided sway;
The rebel flushed in his lusty May:
You did your best, as in you lay,
McClellan.
Antietam's sun-burst sheds a ray.
Your medalled soldiers love you well,
McClellan:
Name your name, their true hearts swell;

With you they shook dread Stonewall's spellBefore the Battle of Malvern Hill, the final clash of the Seven Days Battles and the Peninsula Campaign, McClellan seized a strategic position at Glendale, where the Federal army needed to advance to the James River. Lee sent several divisions, including Major General Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson to attack the Union’s Glendale position, which was located between Malvern Hill and White Oak Swamp. Federal artillery prevented Jackson’s advance through White Oak Swamp (“The Seven Days Battles,” https://www.civilwar.org/learn/articles/seven-days-battles).,
With you they braved the blended yell
Of rebel and maligner fell;
With you in shame or fame they dwell,
McClellan:

Antietam-braves a brave can tellHere Melville uses the trope of native American warrior "braves" to symbolize the commonality between those who fought at Antietam. This also appears in "Apathy and Enthusiasm," "Donelson," and "Running the Batteries," among others..

l.note: Eliza Richards suggests that the last stanza reflects a change in the “line” of support for McClellan mentioned in the first stanza. In the last stanza, McClellan’s support has dwindled as many of the soldiers who loved him have died in battle. Richards reads “deep files” as an image that “evokes both trenches dug as mass graves and swathes of men cut down by mechanized weapons in rows running perpendicular to advancing battle lines” (“Correspondent Lines” 157).

McClellanEliza Richards argues that the poem’s broken lines, cut short to shout “McClellan” in a “one-beat line,” create a visual impression of newspaper and poetry print “full of white spaces and gaps that cannot be closed.” Richards reads this discontinuity in the poem’s lineation as “an analogy to looking around the table and seeing the permanent gaps in a once seemingly solid and infinite black line of force” (“Correspondent Lines” 158). ,
